The long-term health effects of coal pollution, such as respiratory diseases from particulate matter and acid rain, are well-documented but occur over time and are not as immediately catastrophic as a nuclear meltdown.

When all factors are considered—mining accidents, operational risks, and historical incidents—nuclear power has a higher death rate per unit of energy produced than coal. This is not to say coal is without its drawbacks, but in terms of direct fatalities related to energy production, the evidence clearly supports the conclusion that coal is the safer option.
